The server takes the average of control variables 𝒄t+1=𝒄t+1N​(∑i∈𝒮[𝒄it+1−𝒄t])superscript𝒄𝑡1superscript𝒄𝑡1𝑁subscript𝑖𝒮delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑡1superscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t+1}=\bm{c}^{t}+\frac{1}{N}\left(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\left[\bm{c}_{i}^{t+1}-\bm{c}^{t}\right]\right), and re-scales the updates for weights by ηgsubscript𝜂𝑔\eta_{g}, 𝒘t+1=𝒘t+ηg|𝒮|​(∑i∈𝒮[𝒘it−𝒘t])superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝜂𝑔𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡superscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}+\frac{\eta_{g}}{|\mathcal{S}|}\left(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}[\bm{w}_{i}^{t}-\bm{w}^{t}]\right). Note here that ctsuperscript𝑐𝑡c^{t} is taken over all N𝑁N clients. For those that did not participate SCAFFOLD re-uses the previously computed gradients.

The idea behind SCAFFOLD is very intuitive. To solve (1), the ideal (centralized) update is that each client uses all client’s data 𝒘it+1=𝒘t−ηgN​∑i=1N∇Fi​(𝒘t)subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝜂𝑔𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t+1}_{i}=\bm{w}^{t}-\frac{\eta_{g}}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}). However such update rule is not possible in IoFT due to the need to communicate the gradients ∇Fi​(𝒘)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}) with the orchestrator at every optimization iterate. To mimic the ideal update, SCAFFOLD uses 𝒄itsuperscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑡\bm{c}_{i}^{t} to approximates ∇Fi​(𝒘it)∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}) at using the last communication round, for all i𝑖i. Then also 𝒄tsuperscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t} may approximate the gradient of the global risk, 𝒄t=1N​∑i=1N𝒄it≈1N​∑i=1N∇Fi​(𝒘it)superscript𝒄𝑡1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝒄𝑡𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{c}^{t}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{c}^{t}_{i}\approx\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}). If this approximation holds, the update of SCAFFOLD becomes similar to ideal (centralized) update. One caveat in such update scheme is that 𝒄tsuperscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t} may not always equal (or approximate) the ideal value 1N​∑i=1N𝒄it1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝒄𝑡𝑖\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{c}^{t}_{i}. Adding to that, 𝒄tsuperscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t} re-uses the previously computed gradients when clients do not participate. Therefore, when client participation rate is low, 𝒄tsuperscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t} can deviate far away from the ideal update leading to degraded optimization performance.

Empirically, SCAFFOLD requires fewer communication rounds to converge compared with FedAvg. A very similar algorithm is Federated SVRG [149], which applies stochastic variance reduced gradient descent to approximately solve (3). The update rule is 𝒘it,e+1=𝒘it,e−η​(Si​(∇Fi​(𝒘it,e)−𝒄it)+𝒄t)subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑒1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑒𝑖𝜂subscript𝑆𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒄𝑡𝑖superscript𝒄𝑡\bm{w}^{t,e+1}_{i}=\bm{w}^{t,e}_{i}-\eta\left(S_{i}\left(\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t,e}_{i})-\bm{c}^{t}_{i}\right)+\bm{c}^{t}\right), where Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is a diagonal matrix to rescale gradients. Federated SVRG reduces to SCAFFOLD when one sets Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} to the identity matrix.

As discussed, despite its efficiency on several FL tasks, SCAFFOLD does not work well in low client participation cases. To this end, FedDyn [3] uses a specially designed dynamic regularization to align gradients under partial participation. The objective on client i𝑖i is defined as:

min𝒘it⁡Fi​(𝒘it)−⟨∇Fi​(𝒘it−1),𝒘it⟩+μ2​‖𝒘it−𝒘t−1‖2.subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝜇2superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡12\min_{\bm{w}^{t}_{i}}F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}_{i})-\left\langle\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t-1}_{i}),\bm{w}^{t}_{i}\right\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}^{t}_{i}-\bm{w}^{t-1}\right\|^{2}. (5)

Objective (5) is also closely related to (III-B). In (III-B), when the weight 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} is near critical points of the global risk F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\bm{w}), ∇F​(𝒘)∇𝐹𝒘\nabla F(\bm{w}) is close to 00, thus (III-B) reduces to (5). As a simple fixed points analysis, when all models start from 𝒘it−1=𝒘t−1=𝒘∗superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘\bm{w}_{i}^{t-1}=\bm{w}^{t-1}=\bm{w}^{*}, i.e. a critical point of the global loss, the optimal solution of (5) is still 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*}, thus local updates will stay at 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*}. FedDyn is proved to converge to critical points of the global objective with a constant stepsize. Also, to deal with partial client participation, FedDyn uses a SAG-style [284] averaging rule in server_update: instead of only averaging gradients from clients that participated in the training in one communication round, FedDyn estimates gradients on disconnected clients based on historic values and averages all gradients (or gradient estimates). In practice, FedDyn is shown to achieve similar test accuracy with much fewer communication rounds compared with FedAvg and FedProx, especially when client participation rate is low.

A closely related algorithm to FedDyn is Federated primal-dual (FedPD) [359]. FedPD and FedDyn have different formulations, but end up with the same update rule under some conditions. In FedPD, the optimization problem in (1) is reformulated to a constrained optimization problem

min𝒘0,{𝒘i}⁡1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘i)subject to𝒘1=…=𝒘N=𝒘0.subscriptsubscript𝒘0subscript𝒘𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖subject tosubscript𝒘1…subscript𝒘𝑁subscript𝒘0\min_{\bm{w}_{0},\{\bm{w}_{i}\}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i})\quad\text{subject to}\quad\bm{w}_{1}=...=\bm{w}_{N}=\bm{w}_{0}\,. (6)

To solve the constrained optimization problem, FedPD introduces dual variables λ1,⋯,λNsubscript𝜆1⋯subscript𝜆𝑁\lambda_{1},\cdots,\lambda_{N}, then defines the augmented Lagrangian (AL) for client i𝑖i to be ℱi​(𝒘i,λi,𝒘0)=Fi​(𝒘i)+⟨λi,𝒘i−𝒘0⟩+μ2​‖𝒘i−𝒘0‖2subscriptℱ𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝒘0subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝒘0𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝒘02\mathcal{F}_{i}(\bm{w}_{i},\lambda_{i},\bm{w}_{0})=F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i})+\left\langle\lambda_{i},\bm{w}_{i}-\bm{w}_{0}\right\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}_{i}-\bm{w}_{0}\right\|^{2}. FedPD uses alternative descent on primal and dual variables to optimize ℱisubscriptℱ𝑖\mathcal{F}_{i}. More specifically, FedPD first randomly initializes 𝒘0,λi,𝒘isubscript𝒘0subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{0},\lambda_{i},\bm{w}_{i} for all clients. At round t𝑡t, the algorithm updates 𝒘it+1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖\bm{w}^{t+1}_{i} by optimizing ℱisubscriptℱ𝑖\mathcal{F}_{i} and fixing λi=λitsubscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑡\lambda_{i}=\lambda_{i}^{t} and 𝒘0=𝒘0tsubscript𝒘0superscriptsubscript𝒘0𝑡\bm{w}_{0}=\bm{w}_{0}^{t}. It then updates dual variables by λit+1=λit+μ​(𝒘it+1−𝒘0,it)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑡𝜇superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡0𝑖\lambda_{i}^{t+1}=\lambda_{i}^{t}+\mu(\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1}-\bm{w}^{t}_{0,i}) and also 𝒘0,it+1=𝒘it+1+1μ​λit+1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡10𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡11𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1}_{0,i}=\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1}+\frac{1}{\mu}\lambda_{i}^{t+1}. After the local updates, FedPD makes a random choice with probability 1−p1𝑝1-p, that all clients send updated 𝒘0,itsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡0𝑖\bm{w}^{t}_{0,i} back to the orchestrator which updates 𝒘0t+1=1N​∑i=1N𝒘0,it+1superscriptsubscript𝒘0𝑡11𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡10𝑖\bm{w}_{0}^{t+1}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{w}^{t+1}_{0,i} and broadcasts updated 𝒘0t+1superscriptsubscript𝒘0𝑡1\bm{w}_{0}^{t+1}. With probability p𝑝p, all clients set 𝒘0=𝒘0,it+1superscript𝒘0subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡10𝑖\bm{w}^{0}=\bm{w}^{t+1}_{0,i} and continue local training. Interestingly, by letting λi=∇Fi​(𝒘it−1)subscript𝜆𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\lambda_{i}=\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t-1}), it was shown that FedPD is equivalent to FedDyn with full client participation on an algorithmic level [358]. However, different from FedDyn, FedPD does not directly apply to partial participation settings.

Another algorithm that uses a constrained optimization formulation is FedSplit [246]. FedSplit [246] applies Peaceman-Rachford splitting [247, 58]. More specifically, FedSplit concatenates 𝒘1,⋯,𝒘Nsubscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝑁\bm{w}_{1},\cdots,\bm{w}_{N} into one long vector 𝓦=(𝒘1T,…,𝒘NT)T𝓦superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒘1T…superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑁TT\bm{\mathcal{W}}=(\bm{w}_{1}^{\texttt{T}},...,\bm{w}_{N}^{\texttt{T}})^{\texttt{T}} and finds the optimal solution of 1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘i)1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}) on the subspace ℰ={𝓦|𝒘1=⋯=𝒘N}ℰconditional-set𝓦subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝑁\mathcal{E}=\{\bm{\mathcal{W}}|\bm{w}_{1}=\cdots=\bm{w}_{N}\}. The problem is also known as consensus optimization [275]. An important concept in consensus optimization is the normal cone defined as 𝒩ℰ​(𝓦)=ℰ⟂subscript𝒩ℰ𝓦superscriptℰperpendicular-to\mathcal{N}_{\mathcal{E}}(\bm{\mathcal{W}})=\mathcal{E}^{\perp} for 𝓦∈ℰ𝓦ℰ\bm{\mathcal{W}}\in\mathcal{E} and empty otherwise. At the optimal solution, the gradient should be in the normal cone of ℰℰ\mathcal{E}:

0∈∇𝓦​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘i)+𝒩ℰ​(𝓦).0subscript∇𝓦superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝒩ℰ𝓦0\in\nabla_{\bm{\mathcal{W}}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i})+\mathcal{N}_{\mathcal{E}}(\bm{\mathcal{W}})\,.

FedSplit treats gradient ∇𝓦subscript∇𝓦\nabla_{\bm{\mathcal{W}}} and normal cone 𝒩ℰsubscript𝒩ℰ\mathcal{N}_{\mathcal{E}} as two operators, and uses Peaceman-Rachford splitting [58] to find a solution 𝓦𝓦\bm{\mathcal{W}} that satisfies the optimality condition. After some derivations, the authors propose the following update rules. At communication round t𝑡t, clients update their local weights 𝒘itsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}^{t}, send them to server and store a local copy. In the following round, client i𝑖i receives global update 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t}, and calculates:

{𝒘it+12=arg⁡min𝒘i⁡Fi​(𝒘i)+μ2​‖𝒘i−(2​𝒘t−𝒘it)‖2𝒘it+1=𝒘it+2​(𝒘t−𝒘it+12).\left\{\begin{aligned} &\bm{w}_{i}^{t+\frac{1}{2}}=\arg\min_{\bm{w}_{i}}F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}_{i}-\left(2\bm{w}^{t}-\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\\ &\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1}=\bm{w}_{i}^{t}+2\left(\bm{w}^{t}-\bm{w}_{i}^{t+\frac{1}{2}}\right)\,.\end{aligned}\right.

The server_update simply averages 𝒘t+1=1N​∑i=1N𝒘it+1superscript𝒘𝑡11𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1}. Intuitively, operator splitting adds a regularization term centered at 2​𝒘t−𝒘it2superscript𝒘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡2\bm{w}^{t}-\bm{w}_{i}^{t} to the local objective. The carefully designed update rule has two advantages. Firstly it help alleviate client-drift: FedSplit convergences linearly to critical points of the global loss on convex problems. Also, it accelerates convergence: the theoretical convergence rate is faster than that of FedAvg on strongly convex problems.

In addition to algorithms applicable to general federated optimization problems, there are models designed specifically for neural networks to handle heterogeneity. For instance, researchers pointed out that re-permutation of neurons may cause declined performance in the aggregation step of FL. This re-permutation problem is due to the fact that different neural networks created by a weight permutation might represent the same function.

For example, consider a simple NN, f𝒘​(x)=W2​σ​(W1​x)subscript𝑓𝒘𝑥subscript𝑊2𝜎subscript𝑊1𝑥f_{\bm{w}}(x)=W_{2}\sigma\left(W_{1}x\right) where σ𝜎\sigma is an activation function, f𝒘​(x)∈ℝdysubscript𝑓𝒘𝑥superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑦f_{\bm{w}}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{y}}, x∈ℝdx𝑥superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑥x\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{x}} and W1∈ℝw×ℝdxsubscript𝑊1superscriptℝ𝑤superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑥W_{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{w}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{x}} and W2∈ℝdy×ℝwsubscript𝑊2superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑦superscriptℝ𝑤W_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{y}}\times\mathbb{R}^{w} are weight matrices. One can multiply a permutation matrix Π∈ℝw×ℝwΠsuperscriptℝ𝑤superscriptℝ𝑤\Pi\in\mathbb{R}^{w}\times\mathbb{R}^{w} to W1subscript𝑊1W_{1} and W2subscript𝑊2W_{2}, f𝒘​(x)=W2​ΠT​σ​(Π​W1​x)subscript𝑓𝒘𝑥subscript𝑊2superscriptΠT𝜎Πsubscript𝑊1𝑥f_{\bm{w}}(x)=W_{2}\Pi^{\texttt{T}}\sigma\left(\Pi W_{1}x\right), and the function remains the same. However updates on different clients may be attracted to networks with a different permutation matrix ΠΠ\Pi. This can cause averaging over weights to fail. To cope with this, [350] propose a neuron matching algorithm called Probabilistic Federated Neural Matching (PFNM). PFNM assumes Πi​W1subscriptΠ𝑖subscript𝑊1\Pi_{i}W_{1} and W2​ΠiTsubscript𝑊2superscriptsubscriptΠ𝑖TW_{2}\Pi_{i}^{\texttt{T}} are generated by a hierarchical probabilistic model whose hyper-parameters are determined by global weights. Then PFNM uses Bayesian inference to estimate the hyper-parameters, and reconstructs the global model from the inference.

However, [308] argue that PFNM can only work on simple fully connected neural networks. To solve the problem, they extend PFNM to Federated Matched Averaging (FedMA) algorithm. FedMA updates weights of a neural network layer by layer. Firstly, clients train local NNs and send the trained first layer weights Wi(1)subscriptsuperscript𝑊1𝑖W^{(1)}_{i} to the orchestartor, where Wi(1)subscriptsuperscript𝑊1𝑖W^{(1)}_{i} denotes the weight vector of layer 111 from client i𝑖i. The server uses matching algorithms such as the Hungarian algorithm in PFNM to estimate Πi(1)subscriptsuperscriptΠ1𝑖\Pi^{(1)}_{i} that represents the permutation vector of first layer model weights for client i𝑖i. Thus, Πi(1)​Wi(1)subscriptsuperscriptΠ1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑊1𝑖\Pi^{(1)}_{i}W^{(1)}_{i} become the matched weights after re-permutation. The server then averages the results W¯(1)=1N​∑i=1NΠi(1)​Wi(1)superscript¯𝑊11𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptsuperscriptΠ1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑊1𝑖\overline{W}^{(1)}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\Pi^{(1)}_{i}W^{(1)}_{i}, and broadcasts the averaged W¯(1)superscript¯𝑊1\overline{W}^{(1)}. After receiving W¯(1)superscript¯𝑊1\overline{W}^{(1)}, clients continue to train the remaining layers with the first layer fixed to W¯(1)superscript¯𝑊1\overline{W}^{(1)}. A similar match-then-average process repeats for remaining layers. For FedMA, the number of communication rounds equals the number of network layers. FedMA is reported to have strong performance on CIFAR-10 and a well known language dataset called Shakespeare. Additionally, the performance of FedMA improves with the increase of local epochs E𝐸E, while that of FedAvg and FedProx drops after a threshold of E𝐸E due to the discrepancy between local models (i.e. local weights wander away from each other). Thus FedMA enables clients to train more epochs between consecutive communications.

All approaches described above are of a frequentist nature. However, there has also been a recent push on improving global modeling through a Bayesian framework. The intuition is simple; rather than betting our results on one hypothesis (𝒘𝒘\bm{w}) obtained via optimizing the empirical risk, one may average over a set of possible 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} or integrate over all 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} weighted by their posterior probability ℙ​(𝒘|D={D1,⋯,DN})ℙconditional𝒘𝐷subscript𝐷1⋯subscript𝐷𝑁\mathbb{P}(\bm{w}|D=\{D_{1},\cdots,D_{N}\}). This is the underlying philosophy of marginalization compared to optimization, whereby in the frequentist approach predictions are obtained through substituting the posterior by ℙ​(𝒘|D)=δ​(𝒘=𝒘^)ℙconditional𝒘𝐷𝛿𝒘^𝒘\mathbb{P}(\bm{w}|D)=\delta(\bm{w}=\hat{\bm{w}}), where 𝒘^^𝒘\hat{\bm{w}} is the single optimized weight and δ𝛿\delta is an indicator function. Indeed, this notion of Bayesian ensembling has seen a lot of empirical success in Bayesian deep learning [197, 124].

One such approach is Fed-ensemble [288]. Fed-ensemble, is a simple plug-in into any FL algorithm that aims to learn an ensemble of K𝐾K-models without additional communication costs. To do so, Fed-ensemble follows a random permutation sampling scheme where at each communication round, every client trains one of the K𝐾K models and then aggregation happens for each model separately (using FedAvg or other FL approaches). This approach corresponds to a variational inference scheme [27, 354] for estimating a Gaussian mixture variational distribution whose centers are randomly initialized at the beginning. Predictions on a new input x∗superscript𝑥x^{*} are then obtained by taking an average over the predictions of the K𝐾K models

f​(x∗)=1K​∑kf𝒘k​(x⋆).𝑓superscript𝑥1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝑓subscript𝒘𝑘superscript𝑥⋆f(x^{*})=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k}f_{\bm{w}_{k}}(x^{\star})\,. (7)

Fed-ensemble is also able to quantify predictive uncertainty. Using a neural tangent kernel argument, the authors show that all predictions from all K𝐾K models converge to samples from the same limiting Gaussian process in sufficiently overparameterized regimes (see Fig. 7) where each mode can behave like a model trained by centralized training.

Another recent work taking insights from Bayesian inference is FedBE [42]. It performs statistical inference on the client-trained models and uses knowledge-distillation (KD) to update the global model. Intuitively, the goal of KD is to use high-quality base models from a global distribution ℙ​(𝒘)ℙ𝒘\mathbb{P}(\bm{w}) to direct the global model update. More specifically, after receiving {𝒘i}i∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑖𝒮\{\bm{w}_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{S}} from clients, the server fits them with a Gaussian or Dirichlet distribution and then samples from the estimated distribution to form an ensemble of K𝐾K models {𝒘1,⋯,𝒘K}subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝐾\{\bm{w}_{1},\cdots,\bm{w}_{K}\}. Similar to (7), the ensemble prediction on a new point x∗superscript𝑥x^{*} is given by ye​n​s​e​m​b​l​e=1K​∑i=1Kf𝒘k​(x∗)subscript𝑦𝑒𝑛𝑠𝑒𝑚𝑏𝑙𝑒1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑓subscript𝒘𝑘superscript𝑥y_{ensemble}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{K}f_{\bm{w}_{k}}(x^{*}). In server_update, the global model f𝒘subscript𝑓𝒘f_{\bm{w}} is trained to mimic the average prediction of models in the ensemble by minimizing the discrepancy between the two predictions evaluated on an additional unlabeled dataset Daddsuperscript𝐷addD^{\text{add}} on the server:

𝒘t+1=arg⁡min𝒘⁡𝔼x∼Dadd​[Div​(ye​n​s​e​m​b​l​e​(x),f𝒘​(x))],superscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥superscript𝐷adddelimited-[]Divsubscript𝑦𝑒𝑛𝑠𝑒𝑚𝑏𝑙𝑒𝑥subscript𝑓𝒘𝑥\bm{w}^{t+1}=\arg\min_{\bm{w}}\mathbb{E}_{x\sim D^{\text{add}}}\left[\text{Div}(y_{ensemble}(x),f_{\bm{w}}(x))\right]\,,

where Div denotes a divergence measure, here cross-entropy. The updated 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} is then sent to all clients. The authors empirically show that the ensemble and knowledge distillation turns out to be more robust to non-i.i.d. data than FedAvg. This approach however requires storing additional data on server which is not always feasible.

III-C Efficient & Effective optimization

Several studies attempt to improve FedAvg by adopting adaptive optimization algorithms to the FL realm. They show theoretically or empirically that the improved algorithms can converge faster and accelerate global model training. In general, acceleration can be achieved by either improving the server aggregation step (server_update) or client updates (client_update). FedAdam and FedYogi [269] bring the well known Adam [143] and Yogi [268] algorithms to FL through augmenting the server_update function by adaptive stepsizes. More specifically, FedAdam and FedYogi use a second order moment estimate vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t} to adaptively adjust the learning rate. v0subscript𝑣0v_{0} is initialized at the beginning. Upon receiving 𝒘itsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\bm{w}^{t}_{i} from clients, server calculates Δ​𝒘it=𝒘it−𝒘Δsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝒘\Delta\bm{w}^{t}_{i}=\bm{w}^{t}_{i}-\bm{w}, and averages them Δt=∑i∈𝒮1|𝒮|​Δ​𝒘itsubscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑖𝒮1𝒮Δsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\Delta_{t}=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}|}\Delta\bm{w}^{t}_{i}. FedAdam updates vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t} as:

vt=ζ​vt−1+(1−ζ)​Δt2,subscript𝑣𝑡𝜁subscript𝑣𝑡11𝜁superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡2v_{t}=\zeta v_{t-1}+\left(1-\zeta\right)\Delta_{t}^{2}\,,

and FedYogi as:

vt=vt−1−(1−ζ)​Δt2​sign​(vt−Δt2),subscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡11𝜁superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡2signsubscript𝑣𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡2v_{t}=v_{t-1}-\left(1-\zeta\right)\Delta_{t}^{2}\text{sign}(v_{t}-\Delta_{t}^{2})\,,

where ζ𝜁\zeta is a parameter for exponential weighting. The update rule for both FedAdam and FedYogi is:

𝒘t+1=𝒘t+η​Δtvt+ϵ,superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡𝜂subscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡italic-ϵ\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}+\eta\frac{\Delta_{t}}{\sqrt{v_{t}}+\epsilon}\,,

where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is a small constant for numerical stability. Though the proved theoretical convergence rates of FedAdam and FedYogi are only comparable to those of FedAvg, the adaptive methods show strong performance on several FL tasks. Considering the success of adaptive stepsize methods in numerous important fields including language models [306], GANs [339, 285], amongst others, we believe their use in FL is promising. A related algorithm in this vein is federated averaging with server momentum (FedAvgM) [187], which uses server momentum in the server_update step.

Besides modifying server_update, multitudes of algorithms redesign the client_update function. For instance, there are some attempts to expedite local training by combining accelerating techniques in optimization.

FedAc [344] is a federated version of an accelerated SGD. Instead of updating a single variable 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i} as FedAvg does, FedAc updates three sequences {𝒘i,(𝒘i)a​g,(𝒘i)m​d}subscript𝒘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑎𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑚𝑑\{\bm{w}_{i},\left(\bm{w}_{i}\right)^{ag},\left(\bm{w}_{i}\right)^{md}\} iteratively on the client side by the following rules for several steps:

{(𝒘it)m​d←ζ1​𝒘it+(1−ζ1)​(𝒘it)a​g𝒈i←∇Fi​((𝒘it)m​d)(𝒘it)a​g←(𝒘it)m​d−η1​𝒈i𝒘it←(1−ζ2)​𝒘it+ζ2​(𝒘it)m​d−η2​𝒈i.\left\{\begin{aligned} \left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)^{md}&\leftarrow\zeta_{1}\bm{w}_{i}^{t}+\left(1-\zeta_{1}\right)\left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)^{ag}\\ \bm{g}_{i}&\leftarrow\nabla F_{i}(\left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)^{md})\\ \left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)^{ag}&\leftarrow\left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)^{md}-\eta_{1}\bm{g}_{i}\\ \bm{w}_{i}^{t}&\leftarrow\left(1-\zeta_{2}\right)\bm{w}_{i}^{t}+\zeta_{2}\left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)^{md}-\eta_{2}\bm{g}_{i}\,.\\ \end{aligned}\right.

ζ1,ζ2,η1,η2subscript𝜁1subscript𝜁2subscript𝜂1subscript𝜂2\zeta_{1},\zeta_{2},\eta_{1},\eta_{2} are four hyper-parameters. Among them ζ1,ζ2subscript𝜁1subscript𝜁2\zeta_{1},\zeta_{2} are exponential averaging parameters, and η1,η2subscript𝜂1subscript𝜂2\eta_{1},\eta_{2} are stepsize parameters. The server averages 𝒘itsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}^{t} and (𝒘it)a​gsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡𝑎𝑔\left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right)^{ag} from sampled clients, and broadcasts the averaged 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} and (𝒘t+1)a​gsuperscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑎𝑔\left(\bm{w}^{t+1}\right)^{ag}, which clients will take as initialization of 𝒘it+1superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1} and (𝒘it+1)a​gsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1𝑎𝑔\left(\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1}\right)^{ag} in the next communication rounds. The algorithm then proceeds till convergence. [344] theoretically prove that FedAc can achieve a linear convergence rate faster than FedAvg when global risk F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\bm{w}) in (1) is strongly convex. Empirical results show that FedAc saves communication cost when there are many devices in the network.

LoAdaBoost [118] adaptively determines the training epochs of clients by monitoring the training loss on each client and adjusting the training schedule accordingly. More specifically, after one communication round, clients send training losses, in addition to updated weights to the server. The server estimates the median of the training loss Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}, Fm​e​d​i​a​n≔m​e​d​i​a​n​({Fi}i=1,⋯,N)≔subscript𝐹𝑚𝑒𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑛𝑚𝑒𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑛subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖1⋯𝑁F_{median}\coloneqq median(\{F_{i}\}_{i=1,\cdots,N}). In the next round, all clients train for a certain amount of epochs E′2superscript𝐸′2\frac{E^{\prime}}{2}, where E′superscript𝐸′E^{\prime} is the average budget of epochs. If the training loss is lower than Fm​e​d​i​a​nsubscript𝐹𝑚𝑒𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑛F_{median}, the local training is deemed to have reached its goal in this round, and the updated weight will be directly sent back to server. If the training loss is higher than Fm​e​d​i​a​nsubscript𝐹𝑚𝑒𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑛F_{median} on client i𝑖i, then the model underfits client i𝑖i. As a result, LoAdaBoost will train the model on client i𝑖i for extra epochs until the local training loss is lower than Lm​e​d​i​a​nsubscript𝐿𝑚𝑒𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑛L_{median} or the total epochs exceed 32​E32𝐸\frac{3}{2}E, whichever comes faster. Such dynamic training schedules allow LoAdaBoost to take resources of clients into consideration, thus can better utilize computation power on edge devices and enable faster training.

III-D Sampling Clients

Due to the often sheer size and unreliability of edge devices participating within IoFT, not all clients can participate in each communication round of the training process as shown in Algorithm 1. Therefore, choosing the appropriate subset 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} at each communication round between the orchestrator and client is of utmost importance in FL. Here we shed light on some existing schemes, other possible alternatives and their implications.

We first start by noting that an alternative approach to write the global objective in (1) is through giving different weights to client risk function. This is given as

min𝒘⁡F​(𝒘)≔∑i=1Npi​Fi​(𝒘)=𝔼i​[Fi​(𝒘)],≔subscript𝒘𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘subscript𝔼𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\min_{\bm{w}}F(\bm{w})\coloneqq\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}F_{i}(\bm{w})=\mathbb{E}_{i}[F_{i}(\bm{w})]\,, (8)

where pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is a weight such that pi≥0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}\geq 0 and ∑i=1Npi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}=1. In IoFT, it is common to have datasets of different sizes. Thus, a natural choice is to set pi=ninsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛p_{i}=\frac{n_{i}}{n} where n𝑛n is the total data size across all clients n=∑i=1Nni𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑛𝑖n=\sum_{i=1}^{N}n_{i}. Clearly if all clients have the same dataset size nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}, objective (8) reduces to (1).

Indeed, although most algorithms for FL use (1), both FedAvg and FedProx (among the earliest methods) use (8) by adding weights pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}. FedAvg samples clients 𝒮⊆[N]𝒮delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{S}\subseteq[N] uniformly with probability ℙi=1Nsubscriptℙ𝑖1𝑁\mathbb{P}_{i}=\frac{1}{N}, and averages client models with weights proportional to their local dataset size nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}: 𝒘t+1=1∑i∈𝒮ni​∑i∈𝒮ni​𝒘it+1superscript𝒘𝑡11subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1}=\frac{1}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}n_{i}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}n_{i}\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1}. On the other hand, FedProx samples clients with probability ℙi=pi=ninsubscriptℙ𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛\mathbb{P}_{i}=p_{i}=\frac{n_{i}}{n} and averages client models with equal weights: 𝒘t+1=1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮𝒘it+1superscript𝒘𝑡11𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1}. These sampling probability and weights are chosen to make client updates unbiased estimates of global updates - i.e. unbiased estimates of ∑i=1Npi​∇Fi​(𝒘)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}).

However, both sampling schemes may have some drawbacks. For example, uniform sampling may be inefficient since the orchestrator can often sample unreliable clients or clients with very small datasets. Dataset size-based sampling addresses this issue, but it may raise fairness concerns as some clients are rarely sampled and trained. This also makes the training procedure more prone to adversarial clients with large datasets that can directly impact the training process.

To form better sampling schemes and accelerate training, adaptive sampling techniques have also been proposed. These FL algorithms update the sampling probability ℙitsuperscriptsubscriptℙ𝑖𝑡\mathbb{P}_{i}^{t} after each communication round from historical statistics [53, 329, 163, 51]. Such methods usually sample clients on which the model fits worse, more often. Intuitively, when a model incurs high training loss or large gradient norms on client i𝑖i, client i𝑖i is not performing well under the current model and should be trained for more epochs.

There are a range of choices for measuring the performance of a model on the client. Among them, there is a set of literature that calculates the sampling probabilities adaptively using gradient norms of the clients [222, 138, 186]. Generally this can be given as

ℙit∝exp​(γ​‖∇Fi​(𝒘it)‖2),proportional-tosuperscriptsubscriptℙ𝑖𝑡exp𝛾superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖2\mathbb{P}_{i}^{t}\propto\mbox{exp}\left(\gamma{\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}_{i})\right\|^{2}}\right)\,,

where γ𝛾\gamma is some constant. Other approaches sample clients based on their training loss [30, 53] where the gradient is substituted by the local loss Fi​(𝒘it)subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}_{i}) at the end of each training round. In this set of literature, exploration and exploitation schemes are also used to continuously update the sampling probability. Client selection usually improves model performance and speeds up the training process. For example, [163] can achieve 1.2×1.2\times to 14.1×14.1\times speed up in terms of time-to-accuracy compared with vanilla FedProx or FedYogi.

Due to prevailing statistical and system heterogeneity among clients, we believe client sampling techniques will be of great significance when practitioners try to deploy FL frameworks in IoFT. An effective sampling scheme can efficiently exploit differences in client’s resources while at the same time improving training speed and accuracy. Further, studying the connections between adaptive sampling and client re-weighting schemes (see Sec. III-E) used for fairness is an interesting topic worthy of investigation.

III-E Fairness across clients

In IoFT, it is crucial to ensure that all edge devices have good prediction performance. However, the key challenge is that devices with insufficient amounts of data, limited bandwidth, or unreliable internet connection are not favored by conventional FL algorithms. Such devices can potentially end with bad predictive ability. Besides this notion of individual fairness, group fairness also deserves attention in FL. As FL penetrates many practical applications, it is important to achieve fair performance across groups of clients characterized by their gender, ethnicity, etc. Before diving into the literature, we first start by formally defining the notion of fairness. Suppose there are d𝑑d groups (e.g., ethnicity) and each client can be assigned to one of those groups. Group fairness can be defined as follows.

Definition 1.

Denote by {a𝐰i}1≤i≤dsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑖𝐰1𝑖𝑑\{a^{i}_{\bm{w}}\}_{1\leq i\leq d} the set of performance measures (e.g., testing accuracy) of a trained model 𝐰𝐰\bm{w}. For trained models 𝛉𝛉\bm{\theta} and 𝛉~~𝛉\tilde{\bm{\theta}}, we say 𝛉𝛉\bm{\theta} is more fair than 𝛉~~𝛉\tilde{\bm{\theta}} if V​a​r​({a𝛉i}1≤i≤d)<V​a​r​({a𝛉~i}1≤i≤d)𝑉𝑎𝑟subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑖𝛉1𝑖𝑑𝑉𝑎𝑟subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑖~𝛉1𝑖𝑑Var(\{a^{i}_{\bm{\theta}}\}_{1\leq i\leq d})<Var(\{a^{i}_{\tilde{\bm{\theta}}}\}_{1\leq i\leq d}), where V​a​r𝑉𝑎𝑟Var denotes variance.

When d=N𝑑𝑁d=N, this definition is equivalent to the individual fairness. Definition 1 is widely adopted in most FL literature [217, 173, 119, 355, 352]. This notion of fairness might be different from traditional definitions such as demographic disparity [85], equal opportunity and equalized odds [107] in centralized systems. The reason is that those conventional definitions cannot be extended to FL as there is no clear notion of an outcome which is optimal for an edge device [133]. Instead, fairness in FL can be defined as equal access to effective models (e.g., the accuracy disparity [351] or the representation disparity [173]). Specifically, the goal is to train a global model that incurs a uniformly good performance across all devices or groups [133].

Despite the importance of fairness, unfortunately, very limited work exist along this line in FL. As will become clear shortly, the few works in this area mainly focus on a client re-weighting scheme through exploiting the weighted global objective in (8) instead of (1).

GIFAIR-FL [349] is the first algorithm that can handle both group and individual fairness in FL. Specifically, it achieves fairness by penalizing the spread in the loss among client groups. This can be translated to the following optimization problem:

H​(𝒘)=∑i=1Npi​Fi​(𝒘)+λ​∑1≤j<k≤d|Lj​(𝒘)−Lk​(𝒘)|,𝐻𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝜆subscript1𝑗𝑘𝑑subscript𝐿𝑗𝒘subscript𝐿𝑘𝒘\displaystyle H(\bm{w})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}F_{i}(\bm{w})+\lambda\sum_{1\leq j<k\leq d}\left|L_{j}(\bm{w})-L_{k}(\bm{w})\right|,

where λ𝜆\lambda is a regularization parameter and

Lj​(𝒘)=1|𝒜j|​∑i∈𝒜jFi​(𝒘)subscript𝐿𝑗𝒘1subscript𝒜𝑗subscript𝑖subscript𝒜𝑗subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\displaystyle L_{j}(\bm{w})=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{A}_{j}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{A}_{j}}F_{i}(\bm{w})

is the average loss for group j𝑗j and 𝒜jsubscript𝒜𝑗\mathcal{A}_{j} is the set of indices of devices who belong to group i𝑖i. The original formulation of H​(𝒘)𝐻𝒘H(\bm{w}) can be further simplified as

H​(𝒘)=∑i=1Npi​(1+λpi​|𝒜si|​ri​(𝒘))𝐻𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖1𝜆subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒜subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖𝒘\displaystyle H(\bm{w})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}\left(1+\frac{\lambda}{p_{i}|\mathcal{A}_{s_{i}}|}r_{i}(\bm{w})\right)
Fi​(𝒘)≔∑i=1Npi​Hi​(𝒘)≔subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐻𝑖𝒘\displaystyle F_{i}(\bm{w})\coloneqq\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}H_{i}(\bm{w})

where

ri​(𝒘)=∑1≤j≠si≤dsign​(Lsi​(𝒘)−Lj​(𝒘)),subscript𝑟𝑖𝒘subscript1𝑗subscript𝑠𝑖𝑑signsubscript𝐿subscript𝑠𝑖𝒘subscript𝐿𝑗𝒘\displaystyle r_{i}(\bm{w})=\sum_{1\leq j\neq s_{i}\leq d}\text{sign}(L_{s_{i}}(\bm{w})-L_{j}(\bm{w})),

and si∈[d]subscript𝑠𝑖delimited-[]𝑑s_{i}\in[d] is the group index of device i𝑖i. ri​(𝒘)subscript𝑟𝑖𝒘r_{i}(\bm{w}) can be viewed as a scalar that related to the statistical ordering of Lsisubscript𝐿subscript𝑠𝑖L_{s_{i}} among client group losses. Therefore, to collaboratively minimize H​(𝒘)𝐻𝒘H(\bm{w}), each edge device i𝑖i is minimizing Hi​(𝒘)subscript𝐻𝑖𝒘H_{i}(\bm{w}), a scaled version of the original local loss function Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\bm{w}). The central server will aggregate local parameters and update {ri​(𝒘)}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝒘𝑖1𝑁\{r_{i}(\bm{w})\}_{i=1}^{N} at every communication round. From the expression of ri​(𝒘)subscript𝑟𝑖𝒘r_{i}(\bm{w}), one can see that a higher value of ri​(𝒘)subscript𝑟𝑖𝒘r_{i}(\bm{w}) will be assigned to the client that has higher group loss. Therefore, GIFAIR-FL will impose higher weights for clients with bad performances. Furthermore, those weights will be dynamically updated at every communication round to avoid possible model over-fitting. [349] has shown that GIFAIR-FL will converge to an optimal solution or a stationary point even when heterogeneity exists.

Agnostic federated learning (AFL) [217] is another algorithm that re-weights clients at each communication round. Specifically, it solves a robust optimization problem in the form of

min𝒘⁡maxmax⁡p1,…,pN​∑i=1Npi​Fi​(𝒘).subscript𝒘subscriptsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\displaystyle\min_{\bm{w}}\max_{\max{p_{1},\ldots,p_{N}}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}F_{i}(\bm{w}).

AFL computes the worst-case combination of weights among edge devices. This approach is robust but may be conservative since it only focuses on the largest loss and thus causes pessimistic performance to other clients. Du et al. [75] further refine the notation of AFL by linearly parametrizing weight parameters by some kernel functions. Upon that Hu et al. [116] combine minimax optimization with gradient normalization to formulate a new fair algorithm FedMGDA+.

Inspired by fair resource allocation for wireless networks problems, [173] propose the q-FFL algorithm for fairness. They slightly modify the loss function and add a power q𝑞q to each user

min𝒘​∑i=1Npiq+1​Fiq+1​(𝒘).subscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖𝑞1subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑞1𝑖𝒘\min_{\bm{w}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{p_{i}}{q+1}F^{q+1}_{i}(\bm{w}). (9)

The intuition is that q𝑞q tunes the amount of fairness: the algorithm will incur a larger loss to the users with poor performance. Therefore, q-FFL can ensure uniform accuracy across all users.

To the best of our knowledge, fairness is an under-investigated yet critical area in the FL setting. We hope this section can inspire the continued exploration of fair FL algorithms.

IV Learning a Personalized Model

As highlighted in previous sections, heterogeneity is a fundamental challenge for IoFT. IoFT devices often exhibit highly heterogeneous trends and behaviors due to differences in operational, environmental, cultural, socio-economic and specification conditions [152, 153, 348]. For instance, in manufacturing, operational differences involve changes in the speed, load, or temperature a product experiences. As a result, data distribution across edge devices can be vastly heterogeneous, that one single global model cannot perform consistently well on all edge devices. This also has severe fairness implications as devices with limited data and unreliable connection will not be favored by many FL algorithms due to higher weights (recall FedAvg and its variants) given to devices with more data or those that can participate more often in the training process. Indeed, in the past few years, multiple papers have shown the wide gap in a global model’s performance across different devices when heterogeneity exists [131, 106, 312, 293, 133].

One straightforward solution to address the challenges above is through personalization. As shown in Fig. 8, instead of using one global model for all edge devices, personalized FL fits tailor-made models for IoFT devices while levering information across all those devices. The rest of this section will discuss current personalization approaches, their drawbacks and potential alternatives. We divide the personalization techniques into fully personalized and semi-personalized. For fully personalized algorithms, each edge device retains its own individualized model, and for semi-personalized algorithms, models are tailor-made only to a group of clients. In Sec. V, we will further discuss personalization from a meta-learning perspective.

IV-A Fully Personalized

From a statistical perspective, let xi∼ℙxsimilar-tosubscript𝑥𝑖subscriptℙ𝑥x_{i}\sim\mathbb{P}_{x}, but let the conditional distributions of yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} given xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} vary across IoFT devices. One can write this as yi∼ℙy|xi​(f𝜷i​(xi))similar-tosubscript𝑦𝑖subscriptsuperscriptℙ𝑖conditional𝑦𝑥subscript𝑓subscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖y_{i}\sim\mathbb{P}^{i}_{y|x}\big{(}f_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}(x_{i})\big{)} where clients share the same f𝑓f (a linear model, neural network) yet with different parameters 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}. In this situation, the difference in the data distributions ℙx,yi=ℙx​ℙy|xisubscriptsuperscriptℙ𝑖𝑥𝑦subscriptℙ𝑥subscriptsuperscriptℙ𝑖conditional𝑦𝑥\mathbb{P}^{i}_{x,y}=\mathbb{P}_{x}\mathbb{P}^{i}_{y|x} across clients can be explained by the difference in ℙy|xisubscriptsuperscriptℙ𝑖conditional𝑦𝑥\mathbb{P}^{i}_{y|x}. This is often referred to as a concept shift and implies a change in the input-output relationship across clients [299, 211]. For example, in manufacturing the same design setting can have different effects on the manufactured product given external factors such as operational speed or load. Also, take the sequence prediction task on mobile phones as an example: for different users, the word following “I live in …” should be different [156]. This example corresponds to a concept shift: x𝑥x is assumed the given part of the sentence ‘I live in’, and y𝑦y is the next word to predict. In this situation, ℙy|xisubscriptsuperscriptℙ𝑖conditional𝑦𝑥\mathbb{P}^{i}_{y|x} should be customized for different clients even if x𝑥x is the same.

This section discusses current approaches to address a concept shift across clients, their drawbacks, and promising alternatives. Modeling for a shift in ℙxsubscriptℙ𝑥\mathbb{P}_{x} is highlighted in our statistical perspective (Sec. VI-A).

To accommodate client specific concept shifts while leveraging global information one can extend the global FL model in (1) to the following general objective for personalized FL:

min𝒘,𝜷⁡F​(𝒘,𝜷)≔1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘,𝜷i),≔subscript𝒘𝜷𝐹𝒘𝜷1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘subscript𝜷𝑖\min_{\bm{w},\,\bm{\beta}}F(\bm{w},\bm{\beta})\coloneqq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w},\bm{\beta}_{i})\,, (10)

where 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} are shared global parameters while 𝜷={𝜷i}i=1N𝜷superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑖1𝑁\bm{\beta}=\{\bm{\beta}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N} is a set of unique parameters for each client.

The current literature aiming to address a concept shift can be broadly split into two categories: (i) weight sharing and (ii) regularization. It will also become clear shortly that many current approaches follow a train-then-personalize philosophy which may be dangerous in some instances.

IV-A1 Weight Sharing

The first set of literature solves (10) by using different layers of a neural network to represent 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} [311, 179]. The underlying idea is that base layers process the input to learn a shared feature representation across clients, and top layers learn task-dependent weights based on the features.

FedPer [311] fits global base layers, and personalizes top layers. As an example, a fully connected multi-layer neural network can be expressed as f𝒘​(x)=Wl​σ​(Wl−1​σ​(…​σ​(W1​x)))subscript𝑓𝒘𝑥subscript𝑊𝑙𝜎subscript𝑊𝑙1𝜎…𝜎subscript𝑊1𝑥f_{\bm{w}}(x)=W_{l}\sigma\left(W_{l-1}\sigma\left(...\sigma\left(W_{1}x\right)\right)\right), where l𝑙l are the number of network layers. Recall from Sec. III-B, σ𝜎\sigma denotes an activation function and Wjsubscript𝑊𝑗W_{j}’s are weight matrices. In this example, FedPer takes W1subscript𝑊1W_{1} to WBsubscript𝑊𝐵W_{B} as base layers that characterize 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, and WB+1subscript𝑊𝐵1W_{B+1} to Wnsubscript𝑊𝑛W_{n} as personalized layers that characterize 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} in (10). In one communication round, client i𝑖i uses SGD to update 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} simultaneously. However, different from FedAvg, only 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} is transmitted to the server where it is then aggregated. FedPer is found to perform better than FedAvg on image classification tasks such as CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100. On these datasets, the authors show that having the last one or two basic residual blocks of Resnet-34 personalized can yield the best testing performance. Similarly, LG-FedAvg [179] takes top layers as a global weight 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and base layers as personalized weights 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}. The intuition is to learn customized representation layers for different clients, and to train a global model that operates on local representations. Additionally, by carefully designing the loss of representation learning, the generated local representation can confound protected attributes like gender, race, etc.

IV-A2 Regularization

In contrast to splitting of global and local layers, other recent work treat neural networks holistically and learn personalized 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}’s by exploiting regularization [291, 292, 70].

Perhaps the most straightforward method to personalize via regularization is to follow a train-then-personalize (TTP) approach. As the name suggests, this approach trains the global model on all clients then adapts it to individual devices. The simplest way for the adaptation is fine-tuning [343, 8], which is also widely employed in computer vision and natural language processing [258]. More specifically, in the TTP approach, we have a two step procedure. Step 1 - Train: clients collaborate to train a global model 𝒘∗​=Δ​𝒘Tsuperscript𝒘Δsuperscript𝒘𝑇\bm{w}^{*}\overset{\Delta}{=}\bm{w}^{T} using FedAvg (or its variants) - recall T𝑇T is the last communication round. Step 2 - Personalize: clients make small local adjustments based on their local data to personalize 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*}. Notice that for such methods, 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}’s and 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} are in the same parameter space thus it’s possible to perform addition or calculate the difference of these weight vectors. Weight regularizing methods thus usually allow all the weight vector to differ across clients, instead of forcing some coordinates of these weight vectors to be exactly the same.

A simple means for the personalization step is to start from 𝜷i=𝒘∗subscript𝜷𝑖superscript𝒘\bm{\beta}_{i}=\bm{w}^{*} and perform a few steps of SGD to minimize the local loss function min𝜷i⁡Fi​(𝜷i)subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i}). Indeed, this approach to fine-tuning is shown to generalize better than fully local training or global modeling on next word prediction [300] and image classification tasks (e.g. [191, 83]). In this same essence, one may exploit regularization to encourage the weights of personalized models to stay in the vicinity of the global model parameters to balance each client’s shared knowledge and unique characteristics. For instance, using ideas from FedProx, the personalization step can encourage 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} to remain within a vicinity of the global solution 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*} as shown below.

min𝜷i⁡(Fi​(𝜷i)+μ2​‖𝜷i−𝒘∗‖2).subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝜷𝑖superscript𝒘2\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}\left(F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{\beta}_{i}-\bm{w}^{*}\right\|^{2}\right)\,. (11)

Other forms of regularization can also be used. For instance, by employing the popular elastic weight consolidation model (EWC) [144] that is often used in continual learning, we can control 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} as

min𝜷i⁡(Fi​(𝜷i)+μ2​∑jℱ​ℐj​‖βj−wj∗‖2),subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜇2subscript𝑗ℱsubscriptℐ𝑗superscriptnormsubscript𝛽𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑗2\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}\left(F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\sum_{j}\mathcal{FI}_{j}\left\|\beta_{j}-w^{*}_{j}\right\|^{2}\right)\,,

where ℱ​ℐjℱsubscriptℐ𝑗\mathcal{FI}_{j} are diagonal elements of the Fisher information matrix.

Some recent approaches [175, 70] have exploited the ideas above but in an iterative manner, where local and global parameters in the train-then-personalize step are obtained by alternating optimization methods. Among them, Ditto [175] simply proposed the following bi-level optimization problem for client i𝑖i:

min𝜷i⁡Fi​(𝜷i)+μ2​‖𝜷i−𝒘∗‖2subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝜷𝑖superscript𝒘2\displaystyle\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{\beta}_{i}-\bm{w}^{*}\right\|^{2} (12)
s.t.​𝒘∗∈arg⁡min𝒘⁡1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘).s.t.superscript𝒘subscript𝒘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\displaystyle\text{s.t.}\,\bm{w}^{*}\in\arg\min_{\bm{w}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w})\,.

To solve this formulation, Ditto uses the following update rule. In communication round t𝑡t, clients firstly receive a copy of global weight 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t} which is updated to 𝒘it+1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖\bm{w}^{t+1}_{i} using multiple (S)GD steps on the local risk function Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\bm{w}); much like FedAvg. In the meantime, clients i𝑖i also obtains βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} by multiple descent steps on the regularized loss (12):

𝜷i←𝜷i−η​∇Fi​(𝜷i)−η​μ​(𝜷i−𝒘t).←subscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜂𝜇subscript𝜷𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\bm{\beta}_{i}\leftarrow\bm{\beta}_{i}-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})-\eta\mu\left(\bm{\beta}_{i}-\bm{w}^{t}\right).

At the end of the training round, client i𝑖i sends only global weight 𝒘it+1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖\bm{w}^{t+1}_{i} back to server. Server simply averages received weights 𝒘t+1=1N​∑i=1N𝒘it+1superscript𝒘𝑡11𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖\bm{w}^{t+1}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{w}^{t+1}_{i}. Empirically, Ditto has shown strong personalization accuracy on multiple commonly used FL datasets.

In Ditto, the global weight update is independent of personalized weights and follows the FedAvg procedure. Hence global weights cannot learn from the performance of personalized weights. To integrate the update of 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}, [70] proposes Moreau envelope FL (pFedMe) for personalization. pFedMe formulates the following bi-level optimization problem:

min𝒘⁡1N​∑i=1Nmin𝜷i⁡[Fi​(𝜷i)+μ2​‖𝒘−𝜷i‖2].subscript𝒘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜇2superscriptnorm𝒘subscript𝜷𝑖2\min_{\bm{w}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}\left[F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}-\bm{\beta}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right]\,.

pFedMe gets its name because min𝜷i⁡[Fi​(𝜷i)+μ2​‖𝒘−𝜷i‖2]subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜇2superscriptnorm𝒘subscript𝜷𝑖2\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}\left[F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}-\bm{\beta}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right] is the Moreau envelope of Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\bm{w}). In the inner level optimization, personalized weights 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} minimize the local risk function in the vicinity of reference point 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, and in the outer level minimization, 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} is minimized to produce a better reference point. This objective is closely related to model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML). Sec V will cover more details about meta-learning algorithms. The optimal solution of pFedMe satisfies the relation 𝜷i∗​(𝒘)=𝒘−1μ​∇Fi​(𝜷i∗)superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝒘𝒘1𝜇∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}^{*}(\bm{w})=\bm{w}-\frac{1}{\mu}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i}^{*}). Through some calculus, the gradient with respect to 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} is: ∇𝒘[Fi​(𝜷i∗​(𝒘))+μ2​‖𝒘−𝜷i∗​(𝒘)‖2]=μ​(𝜷i∗​(𝒘)−𝒘)subscript∇𝒘subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝒘𝜇2superscriptnorm𝒘superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝒘2𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝒘𝒘\nabla_{\bm{w}}[F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i}^{*}(\bm{w}))+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}-\bm{\beta}_{i}^{*}(\bm{w})\right\|^{2}]=\mu(\bm{\beta}_{i}^{*}(\bm{w})-\bm{w}). In practice, at one communication round, selected clients receive global weight 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and find an approximate optimal solution 𝜷i∗~~superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖\tilde{\bm{\beta}_{i}^{*}} to the inner optimization problem min𝜷i⁡[Fi​(𝜷i)+μ2​‖𝒘−𝜷i‖2]subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜇2superscriptnorm𝒘subscript𝜷𝑖2\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}\left[F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}-\bm{\beta}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right] via SGD or its variants. Client i𝑖i then multiplies the update by μ​ηl𝜇subscript𝜂𝑙\mu\eta_{l}, Δ​𝒘i=μ​ηl​(𝜷i∗~−𝒘)Δsubscript𝒘𝑖𝜇subscript𝜂𝑙~superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝒘\Delta\bm{w}_{i}=\mu\eta_{l}(\tilde{\bm{\beta}_{i}^{*}}-\bm{w}), and sends Δ​𝒘iΔsubscript𝒘𝑖\Delta\bm{w}_{i} to the server. μ𝜇\mu is set to 15∼30similar-to153015\sim 30 in the case studies. The server then averages received Δ​𝒘iΔsubscript𝒘𝑖\Delta\bm{w}_{i} to renew the global model as 𝒘←𝒘+ηg​∑iΔ​𝒘i←𝒘𝒘subscript𝜂𝑔subscript𝑖Δsubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}\leftarrow\bm{w}+\eta_{g}\sum_{i}\Delta\bm{w}_{i}. ηgsubscript𝜂𝑔\eta_{g} is another hyperparameter whose value is 1∼4similar-to141\sim 4 in experiments. With proper hyper-parameter choices, the convergence rate of pFedMe is proved to be faster compared with FedAvg.

Local loopless GD (L2GD) [105] simply sets 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} to be the average of 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}, 𝒘=𝜷¯=1N​∑i=1N𝜷i𝒘¯𝜷1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝜷𝑖\bm{w}=\overline{\bm{\beta}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{\beta}_{i}. The objective is:

min𝜷⁡1N​∑i=1N[Fi​(𝜷i)+μ2​‖𝜷i−𝜷¯‖2].subscript𝜷1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁delimited-[]subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝜷𝑖¯𝜷2\min_{\bm{\beta}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{\beta}_{i}-\overline{\bm{\beta}}\right\|^{2}\right].

To optimize the objective, L2GD chooses to update 1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝜷i)1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i}) and 1N​∑i=1Nμ2​‖𝜷i−𝜷¯‖21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝜷𝑖¯𝜷2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{\beta}_{i}-\overline{\bm{\beta}}\right\|^{2} by a random experiment. More specifically, at round t𝑡t, with probability 1−p1𝑝1-p, each client will perform one step of GD to minimize local training loss 𝜷itsuperscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡\bm{\beta}_{i}^{t} as 𝜷it←𝜷it−ηN​(1−p)​∇Fi​(𝜷)←superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡𝜂𝑁1𝑝∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝜷\bm{\beta}_{i}^{t}\leftarrow\bm{\beta}_{i}^{t}-\frac{\eta}{N(1-p)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{\beta}). With probability 1−p1𝑝1-p, clients will send updated models 𝜷itsuperscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡\bm{\beta}_{i}^{t} back to the server, unless the model is not updated since the previous synchronisation. The server_update consists of two steps: first, the server takes the average of 𝜷itsuperscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡\bm{\beta}_{i}^{t} to obtain 𝜷t¯=1N​∑i=1N𝒘it¯superscript𝜷𝑡1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\overline{\bm{\beta}^{t}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{w}_{i}^{t}; second, the server calculates the initialization of client i𝑖i’s weight on the t+1𝑡1t+1-th communication round as 𝜷it+1=(1−α​μN​p)​𝜷it+α​μN​p​𝜷t¯superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡11𝛼𝜇𝑁𝑝superscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡𝛼𝜇𝑁𝑝¯superscript𝜷𝑡\bm{\beta}_{i}^{t+1}=\left(1-\frac{\alpha\mu}{Np}\right)\bm{\beta}_{i}^{t}+\frac{\alpha\mu}{Np}\overline{\bm{\beta}^{t}} and sends it to the corresponding client. Here α𝛼\alpha is a tunable hyperparameter.

Finally we shed light on another formulation of the train then personalize approach provided by [65]. [65] learn the global parameter 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*} using traditional global modeling approaches, yet, in the personalization step the local objective is given as

min𝜷i⁡Fi​(ζi​𝜷i+(1−ζi)​𝒘∗),subscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜁𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖1subscript𝜁𝑖superscript𝒘\min_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}F_{i}(\zeta_{i}\bm{\beta}_{i}+(1-\zeta_{i})\bm{w}^{*}), (13)

The tuning parameter ζisubscript𝜁𝑖\zeta_{i} balances the importance of the local and global model. When users data are i.i.d., the authors argue that the global model will have better generalization and suggest choosing a smaller ζisubscript𝜁𝑖\zeta_{i}. On the other hand, when data are heterogeneous, they choose to use a larger ζisubscript𝜁𝑖\zeta_{i} to encourage personalization.

IV-A3 A counter-example

The rationale behind regularization approaches is that the global model learns shared knowledge. Then, by encouraging local weights to stay close to the global model, every client can borrow strength from this shared knowledge. Unfortunately, this simple intuition does not apply to all problems. As a simple counterexample, assume client i𝑖i’s ground truth is a sine function:

fθi​(x)=sin⁡(2​π​(x+θi)),subscript𝑓subscript𝜃𝑖𝑥2𝜋𝑥subscript𝜃𝑖f_{\theta_{i}}(x)=\sin(2\pi(x+\theta_{i}))\,,

where θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} is client-dependent. We assume that among clients, θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} admits a uniform distribution on [0,1]01[0,1]. Sine functions are the basis of almost all periodic functions and a phase shift is common for vibration signals, which usually have strong similarity and large shifts.

Now, if we train a global model to minimize the population risk:

min𝒘⁡𝔼i​[‖f𝒘−fθi‖22].subscript𝒘subscript𝔼𝑖delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑓𝒘subscript𝑓subscript𝜃𝑖22\min_{\bm{w}}\mathbb{E}_{i}[||f_{\bm{w}}-f_{\theta_{i}}||_{2}^{2}]\,.

where f𝒘subscript𝑓𝒘f_{\bm{w}} is a global model parametrized by weight 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, and ||⋅||2||\cdot||_{2} is a functional on [0,1]01[0,1] defined as:

‖f‖22=∫01f​(x)2​𝑑x.superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑓22superscriptsubscript01𝑓superscript𝑥2differential-d𝑥||f||_{2}^{2}=\int_{0}^{1}f(x)^{2}dx\,.

Then f𝒘subscript𝑓𝒘f_{\bm{w}} should minimize:

arg⁡minf𝒘⁡𝔼θi​[∫01(f𝒘​(x)−sin⁡(2​π​x+2​π​θi))2​𝑑x]subscriptsubscript𝑓𝒘subscript𝔼subscript𝜃𝑖delimited-[]superscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscript𝑓𝒘𝑥2𝜋𝑥2𝜋subscript𝜃𝑖2differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\arg\min_{f_{\bm{w}}}\mathbb{E}_{\theta_{i}}\left[\int_{0}^{1}\left(f_{\bm{w}}(x)-\sin(2\pi x+2\pi\theta_{i})\right)^{2}dx\right]
=arg⁡minf𝒘⁡𝔼θi​[∫01f𝒘​(x)2−2​f𝒘​(x)​sin⁡(2​π​x+2​π​θi)​d​x]absentsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝒘subscript𝔼subscript𝜃𝑖delimited-[]superscriptsubscript01subscript𝑓𝒘superscript𝑥22subscript𝑓𝒘𝑥2𝜋𝑥2𝜋subscript𝜃𝑖𝑑𝑥\displaystyle=\arg\min_{f_{\bm{w}}}\mathbb{E}_{\theta_{i}}\left[\int_{0}^{1}f_{\bm{w}}(x)^{2}-2f_{\bm{w}}(x)\sin(2\pi x+2\pi\theta_{i})dx\right]
=arg⁡minf𝒘⁡𝔼θi​[∫01f𝒘​(x)2​𝑑x].absentsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝒘subscript𝔼subscript𝜃𝑖delimited-[]superscriptsubscript01subscript𝑓𝒘superscript𝑥2differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=\arg\min_{f_{\bm{w}}}\mathbb{E}_{\theta_{i}}\left[\int_{0}^{1}f_{\bm{w}}(x)^{2}dx\right].

Therefore, the unique minimizer is f𝒘​(x)=0subscript𝑓𝒘𝑥0f_{\bm{w}}(x)=0 for every x𝑥x in [0,1]01[0,1]. Clearly, a global model does not learn anything from such a dataset. Now, assume there exists such a weight vector 𝒘z​e​r​osubscript𝒘𝑧𝑒𝑟𝑜\bm{w}_{zero} such that f𝒘z​e​r​o=0subscript𝑓subscript𝒘𝑧𝑒𝑟𝑜0f_{\bm{w}_{zero}}=0. Now examine the performance of personalized FL models. Ditto’s local objective in (12) becomes a local empirical risk plus a regularization:

∫01(f𝜷i​(x)−sin⁡(2​π​x+2​π​θi))2​𝑑x+μ2​‖𝜷i−𝒘z​e​r​o‖2.superscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscript𝑓subscript𝜷𝑖𝑥2𝜋𝑥2𝜋subscript𝜃𝑖2differential-d𝑥𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝜷𝑖subscript𝒘𝑧𝑒𝑟𝑜2\int_{0}^{1}\left(f_{\bm{\beta}_{i}}(x)-\sin\left(2\pi x+2\pi\theta_{i}\right)\right)^{2}dx+\frac{\mu}{2}||\bm{\beta}_{i}-\bm{w}_{zero}||^{2}.

Not only no useful information about common patterns in the sine function is shared among clients, the regularization will further exacerbate the problem by forcing 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} close to 𝒘z​e​r​osubscript𝒘𝑧𝑒𝑟𝑜\bm{w}_{zero} which is clearly a bad point as its predicts a zero everywhere on the function. Similar phenomena can be witnessed on other regularization based train-then-personalize approaches such as L2GD.

In the example above, data across clients have strong commonalities as they all share the same functional form with only one parameter θ𝜃\theta explaining their variations. Nevertheless, a train-then-personalize approach or its iterative counterparts fail due to a faulty global model. So what are potential alternative approaches ?

IV-A4 Alternative solutions

One approach to circumvent the need for a global model in FL is through multi-task learning (MTL) which aims to leverage commonalities across different but related outputs to improve prediction and learning accuracy [36]. In MTL, a shared representation across all tasks is built to allow the inductive transfer of knowledge [346, 152]. Here each task is a client/edge device.

An illustrative example of MTL vs train-then-personalize is shown in Fig. 10. The main difference is that MTL directly estimates 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} without the need to learn a global model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}.

Often, the shared representation in MTL is induced via regularization to facilitate information transfer across tasks. This can be written as

min𝜷,Ω⁡{1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝜷i)+ℛ​(ℬ,Ω)},subscript𝜷Ω1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜷𝑖ℛℬΩ\displaystyle\min_{\bm{\beta},\Omega}\left\{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{\beta}_{i})+\mathcal{R}(\mathcal{B},\Omega)\right\}\,,

where 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i} are the personalized weights, B𝐵B is a matrix whose i𝑖ith row is 𝜷isubscript𝜷𝑖\bm{\beta}_{i}, ℛℛ\mathcal{R} is a regularization term and ΩΩ\Omega is an N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N matrix that models relationships amongst clients.

The formulation above has been studied extensively in centralized regimes [254, 157, 136, 360, 97]. Yet literature on MTL in FL is still very limited. One of such approaches is MOCHA [291] which defines the objective below

min𝜷,Ω​∑i=1Nℓ​(𝜷i𝚃​xi,yi)+μ1​Tr​(ℬT​Ω​ℬ)+μ2​‖ℬ‖F2,subscript𝜷Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝚃subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜇1TrsuperscriptℬTΩℬsubscript𝜇2superscriptsubscriptnormℬ𝐹2\min_{\bm{\beta},\Omega}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\ell(\bm{\beta}_{i}^{\mathtt{T}}x_{i},y_{i})+\mu_{1}\text{Tr}\left(\mathcal{B}^{\texttt{T}}\Omega\mathcal{B}\right)+\mu_{2}\left\|\mathcal{B}\right\|_{F}^{2}\,,

where, the first term defines a loss function for linear models, Tr​(ℬT​Ω​ℬ)TrsuperscriptℬTΩℬ\text{Tr}\left(\mathcal{B}^{\texttt{T}}\Omega\mathcal{B}\right) induces knowledge transfer such that negative off-diagonal entries of ΩΩ\Omega encourages the alignment of two clients’ local weights and ∥⋅∥F\left\|\cdot\right\|_{F} represents a Frobenius norm for shrinkage. [291] extends the primal-dual formulation in [360] to distribute the update of ℬℬ\mathcal{B} over clients while keeping ΩΩ\Omega fixed. MOCHA is shown to outperform baseline algorithms on datasets including GLEAM, Human Activity Recognition, and Vehicle Sensors.

Although the idea of MOCHA is intriguing the objective is only confined to the problems whose losses are convex, since the authors use dual algorithms to solve it and strong duality is not guaranteed for general non-convex functions. Here, future work that exploit MTL to learn a graphical model through ΩΩ\Omega may open interesting new research directions in understanding the underlying commonality structure across clients.

It is also worth noting that other alternative routes can be taken instead of MTL. One such route is to first validate the performance of a the global model prior to personalization. Along this line, Fed-ensemble [288] proposes an alternative approach for personalization via the learned K𝐾K global models described in Sec. III-B. After training a diverse group of K𝐾K models, Fed-ensemble evaluates the loss of model k𝑘k on a local validation dataset Divalsubscriptsuperscript𝐷val𝑖D^{\mbox{val}}_{i} by F^k,i=1ni​∑j=1niℓ​(f𝒘k​(xi,j),yi,j)subscript^𝐹𝑘𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖ℓsubscript𝑓subscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗\hat{F}_{k,i}=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\ell(f_{\bm{w}_{k}}(x_{i,j}),y_{i,j}). Then each model 𝒘ksubscript𝒘𝑘\bm{w}_{k} is assigned a weight αk,i=exp⁡(−γ​F^k,i)/∑k=1Kexp⁡(−γ​F^k,i)subscript𝛼𝑘𝑖𝛾subscript^𝐹𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝛾subscript^𝐹𝑘𝑖\alpha_{k,i}=\exp(-\gamma\hat{F}_{k,i})/\sum_{k=1}^{K}\exp(-\gamma\hat{F}_{k,i}) where γ𝛾\gamma is some constant. The prediction on a new sample x∗superscript𝑥x^{*} is given by a weighted ensemble ∑k=1Kαk,i​f𝒘k​(x∗)superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑖subscript𝑓subscript𝒘𝑘superscript𝑥\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,i}f_{\bm{w}_{k}}(x^{*}). The intuition is to check which models perform well on a local dataset, then assigns higher weights αk,isubscript𝛼𝑘𝑖\alpha_{k,i} to better fitted models in the ensemble.

IV-B Semi-personalized

A possible alternative to global or fully personalized modeling is semi-personalized modeling. Semi-personalized FL fits a stylized model for a group of clients. This approach balances between the need for N𝑁N individualized models or one model that fits all. This is highlighted in Fig. 11 . Usually these algorithms cluster clients into G<<Nmuch-less-than𝐺𝑁G<<N groups and assume the data distribution of clients inside one group is homogeneous.

[204] proposed an intuitive user clustering method. The number of clusters G<N𝐺𝑁G<N is predetermined. Each cluster is represented by a cluster parameter in {𝒘1,…​𝒘G}subscript𝒘1…subscript𝒘𝐺\{\bm{w}_{1},...\bm{w}_{G}\}. The objective is:

min{𝒘1,…​𝒘G}​∑i=1Nminj∈1,⋯,G⁡Fi​(𝒘j)subscriptsubscript𝒘1…subscript𝒘𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑗1⋯𝐺subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑗\min_{\{\bm{w}_{1},...\bm{w}_{G}\}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\min_{j\in 1,\cdots,G}F_{i}(\bm{w}_{j})

The inner level of minimization taken over cluster index j𝑗j assigns one client i𝑖i to the cluster with the lowest training loss, and the outer level of minimization taken over 𝒘jsubscript𝒘𝑗\bm{w}_{j}’s optimizes cluster model weights. Authors propose a HypCluster algorithm to optimize the objective. In HypCluster, G𝐺G is predetermined. In each communication round, all cluster weights are broadcasted to all clients, and each client chooses one with the lowest loss. Afterwards, clients train the corresponding model by SGD on their own local dataset. On EMNIST, HypCluster with G=2𝐺2G=2 has higher test accuracy than FedAvg and AFL [216].

Clustered FL (CFL) [282] clusters clients dynamically. CFL measures the similarity between two clients in the following manner: suppose in communication round t𝑡t, the update of clients i𝑖i and j𝑗j is Δ​𝒘itΔsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\Delta\bm{w}_{i}^{t} and Δ​𝒘jtΔsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑗𝑡\Delta\bm{w}_{j}^{t}, respectively. The cosine similarity is defined as αi​j=⟨Δ​𝒘it,Δ​𝒘jt⟩‖Δ​𝒘it‖​‖Δ​𝒘jt‖subscript𝛼𝑖𝑗Δsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑗𝑡normΔsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡normΔsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑗𝑡\alpha_{ij}=\frac{\left\langle\Delta\bm{w}_{i}^{t},\Delta\bm{w}_{j}^{t}\right\rangle}{\left\|\Delta\bm{w}_{i}^{t}\right\|\left\|\Delta\bm{w}_{j}^{t}\right\|}. For one communication round, server calculates the cosine similarity intra and across clusters. If clients in one cluster are homogeneous, the similarity of these clients should be large compared with similarity across clusters, then CFL simply performs FedAvg for this cluster. If otherwise, clients inside one cluster are heterogeneous, the similarity of these clients is low, and CFL will divide them into two subclusters. CFL then repeats the procedure on the two subclusters. As the algorithm proceeds, clients can automatically be divided into different subclusters. CFL ends when gradient norms on all clients are small and no further sub-dividing is needed.

Semi-personalized modeling and client clustering in IoFT are important questions that still require much further investigation. In the statistical perspective (Sec. VI) we pose some open questions that are critical along this research direction.

V Meta-Learning

Meta-learning is the science of observing how different learning algorithms perform on a wide range of tasks and then learning new tasks more efficiently based on prior experience [305, 50, 112, 220, 229, 266]. Meta-learning tries to learn a global model that can quickly adapt to a new task with only a few training samples and optimization steps. This process is also known as “Learning to Learn Fast,” where the goal of the model is not to perform well on all tasks in expectation, instead to find a good initialization that can directly adapt to a specific task. Therefore, meta-learning can be viewed as an approach to enable fast personalization and fine-tuning.

Meta-learning opens a unique opportunity to resolve many challenges in IoFT, such as scalability, fast adaptability, and improved generalization. With proper prior knowledge, a well-trained task can be rapidly generalized to new tasks with few samples. This few-shot property becomes especially crucial in IoFT where each device only has a small amount of data and does not have access to a centralized repository of all datasets.

V-A Frequentist Perspective

From a frequentist perspective, the seminal work of Finn et al. [88] proposed one of the first model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML) algorithms. Given N𝑁N different tasks {𝒯i}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒯𝑖𝑖1𝑁\{\mathcal{T}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N}, MAML optimizes a meta-loss function in the form of

min𝒘​∑i=1NF𝒯i​(𝒘−η​∇F𝒯i​(𝒘)).subscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹subscript𝒯𝑖𝒘𝜂∇subscript𝐹subscript𝒯𝑖𝒘\min_{\bm{w}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(\bm{w}-\eta\nabla F_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(\bm{w})). (14)

In (14), 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} can be viewed as an initialization used to perform one gradient update and obtain 𝒘′=𝒘−η​∇F𝒯i​(𝒘)superscript𝒘′𝒘𝜂∇subscript𝐹subscript𝒯𝑖𝒘\bm{w}^{\prime}=\bm{w}-\eta\nabla F_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(\bm{w}). MAML minimizes the objective ∑F𝒯i​(𝒘′)subscript𝐹subscript𝒯𝑖superscript𝒘′\sum F_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(\bm{w}^{\prime}) given an initial parameter 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}. Therefore, the goal of MAML is to find an optimal initial parameter 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*} such that one gradient step on a new task can incur maximally effective behavior on that task. This idea is similar to fine-tuning in which several steps of gradients are performed given a tuned parameter 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*}.

The idea of meta-learning can be naturally extended to FL where each device is treated as a task and the goal is to learn an initialization for fast personalization on the edge devices. Indeed, recently researchers have tried to introduce the notion of meta-learning to FL to enable personalization and few-shot learning [174, 211]. Along this line, [39], [181] and [82] introduce MAML to FL. They reformulate the global objective of FL as (15). In the meta-learning literature, this global objective function is also known as meta-loss. In this section, we will use them interchangeably.

min𝒘⁡1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘−η​∑e=1E∇Fie​(𝒘)).subscript𝒘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑒1𝐸∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑒𝑖𝒘\min_{\bm{w}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w}-\eta\sum_{e=1}^{E}\nabla F^{e}_{i}(\bm{w})). (15)

Here, ∇Fie​(𝒘)∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑒𝑖𝒘\nabla F^{e}_{i}(\bm{w}) is the gradient after e𝑒e steps of SGD. Recall that t𝑡t refers to the communication round, while e∈{0,⋯,E−1}𝑒0⋯𝐸1e\in\{0,\cdots,E-1\} denotes the optimization iterates at the edge device. It is easy to see that (15) is different from the conventional objective function (1). The formulation (15) allows each user to exploit 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} as an initial point and update it with respect to its local data (e.g., running E𝐸E steps of gradient descent). When E=1𝐸1E=1, the above objective function can be simplified as

1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘−η​∇Fi1​(𝒘))=1N​∑i=1NFi​(𝒘−η​∇Fi​(𝒘))1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝜂∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹1𝑖𝒘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w}-\eta\nabla F^{1}_{i}(\bm{w}))=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bm{w}-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})) (16)

and the gradient on device i𝑖i can be computed as

∇Fi​(𝒘−η​∇Fi​(𝒘))=(I−η​∇2Fi​(𝒘))​∇Fi​(𝒘−η​∇Fi​(𝒘)).∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝐼𝜂superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\begin{split}&\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}))\\ &=\big{(}I-\eta\nabla^{2}F_{i}(\bm{w})\big{)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})).\end{split} (17)

Based on this formulation, [82] propose the Per-FedAvg algorithm to efficiently optimize (15). Given an initial parameter 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t}, local user i𝑖i runs E𝐸E steps of SGD. For simplicity, we assume E=1𝐸1E=1. Therefore,

𝒘it=𝒘t−η1​∇Fi​(𝒘t),superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝜂1∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\bm{w}_{i}^{t}=\bm{w}^{t}-\eta_{1}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}), (18)

where η1subscript𝜂1\eta_{1} is the learning rate for each local user. Afterwards, each local user calculates the gradient evaluated at 𝒘itsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}^{t} and the Hessian evaluated at 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t}. The user then sends the gradient ∇Fi​(𝒘it)∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t}) and the Hessian ∇2Fi​(𝒘t)superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\nabla^{2}F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) back to the central server. The central server aggregates them as:

𝒘t+1=𝒘t−η2​1N​∑i=1N(I−η1​∇2Fi​(𝒘t))​∇Fi​(𝒘it),superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝜂21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁𝐼subscript𝜂1superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}-\eta_{2}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\big{(}I-\eta_{1}\nabla^{2}F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}_{i}),

where η2subscript𝜂2\eta_{2} is a learning rate on the central server. This procedure is repeated several times till some exit conditions are met. One notable thing is that, in the central server, the gradient is evaluated at 𝒘itsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}^{t} rather than 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t}. This naturally arises from the meta-loss function (15). [82] demonstrate the advantages of Per-FedAvg on image classification tasks. Interestingly, [131] interpret FedAvg as the linear combination of FedSGD and MAML when ignoring the second-order term η​∇2Fi​(𝒘)𝜂superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\eta\nabla^{2}F_{i}(\bm{w}) in (17). Specifically, assume each client runs E𝐸E steps of local updates, then the gradient of FedAvg can be written as

gF​e​d​A​v​gsubscript𝑔𝐹𝑒𝑑𝐴𝑣𝑔\displaystyle g_{FedAvg}

where gFedSGDsubscript𝑔FedSGDg_{\texttt{FedSGD}} is the gradient of FedSGD and gM​A​M​L​(e)subscript𝑔𝑀𝐴𝑀𝐿𝑒g_{MAML}(e) is the gradient of MAML with e𝑒e steps of local updates. Though the optimization of this linear combination in (V-A) is not strictly equivalent to FedAvg (due to the second-order term), this interpretation sheds light on the intrinsic connection between FL and meta-learning.

Based on this observation, [131] slightly modify the Per-FedAvg algorithm as follows: first run FedAvg (or another conventional FL algorithm) at the early stage of training and then switch to MAML (in (15)) or Reptile [228] to fine-tune the model. Through many empirical results, the authors argue that this combined strategy ensures fast and stable convergence compared to directly optimizing the federated MAML objective in (15). Besides, this paper also delivers an important message: no single FL is a panacea for all problems, instead, differnet dataset requires different inference strategies or a combination of them.

There are also few other variants of meta-learning-algorithms that can be readily applied to FL. For instance, MetaSGD [177, 39] specifies a coordinate-wise learning rate 𝜼𝜼\bm{\eta}. Instead of constraining the learning rate to be a fixed positive scalar, they define 𝜼𝜼\bm{\eta} as a vector that is of the same size as 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and each element in it can be positive, negative or zero. Different from the traditional definition of a learning rate, 𝜼𝜼\bm{\eta} encodes both the update direction and rate. To understand the intuition behind 𝜼𝜼\bm{\eta}, it is very helpful to first see the MetaSGD procedure in detail. In MetaSGD, both 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and 𝜼𝜼\bm{\eta} are treated as model parameters to optimize. Specifically, at communication round t𝑡t, MetaSGD first samples 𝒮⊆[N]𝒮delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{S}\subseteq[N] clients and divides the data for each client into a training set Dtrainsuperscript𝐷trainD^{\text{train}} and validation set Dvalsuperscript𝐷valD^{\text{val}}. Here, MetaSGD then runs one step of SGD using 𝜼tsuperscript𝜼𝑡\bm{\eta}^{t} and 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t} on each sampled client to obtain updated parameters {𝒘it}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝑖1𝑁\{\bm{w}^{t}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N}:

𝒘it←𝒘t−𝜼t∘∇Fi​(𝒘t)←subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡superscript𝜼𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t}_{i}\leftarrow\bm{w}^{t}-\bm{\eta}^{t}\circ\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})

where ∘\circ is a element-wise product operation and Fi​(𝒘t)subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) is the loss function evaluated on the training set at communication round t𝑡t. Afterward, MetaSGD updates all model parameters as

(𝒘t+1,𝜼t+1)←(𝒘t,𝜼t)−ηMetaSGD​1N​∑i=1N∇Fival​(𝒘it)←superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝜼𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡superscript𝜼𝑡subscript𝜂MetaSGD1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹val𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\displaystyle(\bm{w}^{t+1},\bm{\eta}^{t+1})\leftarrow(\bm{w}^{t},\bm{\eta}^{t})-\eta_{\texttt{MetaSGD}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla F^{\text{val}}_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}_{i})

where ηMetaSGDsubscript𝜂MetaSGD\eta_{\texttt{MetaSGD}} is a scalar learning rate and ∇Fival​(𝒘it)∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹val𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\nabla F^{\text{val}}_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}_{i}) is the local gradient evaluated on the validation set Dvalsuperscript𝐷valD^{\text{val}}. Note that 𝒘itsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\bm{w}^{t}_{i} is a function of both 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t} and 𝜼tsuperscript𝜼𝑡\bm{\eta}^{t} since 𝒘it←𝒘t−𝜼t∘∇Fi​(𝒘t)←subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡superscript𝜼𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t}_{i}\leftarrow\bm{w}^{t}-\bm{\eta}^{t}\circ\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}). Therefore, the gradient of Fi​(𝒘it)subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖F_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}_{i}) can be taken with respect to 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t} and 𝜼tsuperscript𝜼𝑡\bm{\eta}^{t}. From this algorithm, one can see that 𝜼𝜼\bm{\eta} is learned from all tasks to avoid possible model over-fitting on a specific task. The intuition is that the gradient ∇Fi​(𝒘i)∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}) on the training set can potentially lead to over-fitting, especially when the sample size is small. Therefore, 𝜼𝜼\bm{\eta} acts as a regularization role to control the sign and magnitude of ∇Fi​(𝒘i)∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}).

V-B Bayesian Perspective

Besides the frequentist perspective on meta-learning, there are recent yet few efforts to explore Bayesian meta-learning. Below we discuss some recent advances. We note that the works discussed below focus on meta-learning and not FL. However as shown earlier those concepts are naturally related. We will also provide examples on how to extend the models to FL.

Bayesian meta-learning simply defines 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} as a random variable and takes a Bayesian route to estimate its posterior. This posterior then serves as a “prior” for a new task. Such an approach would allow uncertainty quantification for predictions on both the central server and local clients [314]. Notably, [341] propose a Bayesian counterpart of MAML (BMAML) for fast adaption and uncertainty quantification.

Instead of finding a single parameter to minimize (15), BMAML aims at finding a posterior distribution of the parameter such that one can quantify uncertainties. To achieve so, the gradient method used in MAML is replaced by one of its Bayesian counterparts - Stein variational gradient descent (SVGD) [185]. The SVGD method combines the strengths of SGD and Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) such that one can sample from a posterior distribution to quantify uncertainties. As described in [185], SVGD maintains M𝑀M instances of model parameters, called particles. Those particles can be viewed as samples from the posterior distribution of the model parameter.

Here we detail the BMAML algorithm. At the global optimization iterate t𝑡t, which is equivalent to the communication round in the FL, BMAML starts with M𝑀M initial particles {𝒘mt}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{\bm{w}^{t}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M} that are sent to the clients. Each client then applies E𝐸E steps of SVGD to obtain updated parameters as shown below:

{𝒘i,mt,E}m=1M=S​V​G​D​({𝒘mt}m=1M;Di,η),superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝐸𝑖𝑚𝑚1𝑀𝑆𝑉𝐺𝐷superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑚𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐷𝑖𝜂\displaystyle\{\bm{w}^{t,E}_{i,m}\}_{m=1}^{M}=SVGD(\{\bm{w}^{t}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M};D_{i},\eta)\,,

where η𝜂\eta and S​V​G​D​({𝒘i,mt}m=1M;D,η)𝑆𝑉𝐺𝐷superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝑚𝑚1𝑀𝐷𝜂SVGD(\{\bm{w}^{t}_{i,m}\}_{m=1}^{M};D,\eta) is the SVGD algorithm that aims to collect samples from the posterior ℙ​(𝒘|Di)ℙconditional𝒘subscript𝐷𝑖\mathbb{P}(\bm{w}|D_{i}) during local training.

Afterwards, the updated task-dependent parameters {𝒘i,mt,E}i∈[N],m∈[M]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝐸𝑖𝑚formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑁𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\{\bm{w}^{t,E}_{i,m}\}_{i\in[N],m\in[M]} are used to calculate the gradient of the meta-loss ∑i∇Fi​({𝒘i,mt,E}m=1M)subscript𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝐸𝑖𝑚𝑚1𝑀\sum_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\{\bm{w}^{t,E}_{i,m}\}_{m=1}^{M}) and perform a one step update

{𝒘mt+1}m=1M←{𝒘mt}m=1M−η​1N​∑i∇Fi​({𝒘i,mt,E}m=1M).←superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑚𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑚𝑚1𝑀𝜂1𝑁subscript𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝐸𝑖𝑚𝑚1𝑀\displaystyle\{\bm{w}^{t+1}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M}\leftarrow\{\bm{w}^{t}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M}-\eta\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\{\bm{w}^{t,E}_{i,m}\}_{m=1}^{M}).

Recall that the gradient of the meta-loss is evaluated at the updated particles {𝒘i,mt,E}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝐸𝑖𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{\bm{w}^{t,E}_{i,m}\}_{m=1}^{M} and the global optimization is performed over {𝒘mt}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{\bm{w}^{t}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M}.
